unnormalised: **The Rollercoaster of Results: A Student's Perspective**
normalised: **The Rollercoaster of Results: A Student's Perspective**

unnormalised: So, results season is upon us again! Honestly, it's like waiting for the monsoon – you know it's coming, you're kinda prepared, but the actual downpour can still catch you off guard. This year, the Class 12 results from CBSE were announced on 15/05/2024, and the whole country went into a collective frenzy, I swear! My younger brother, Rohan, was one of the victims, er, I mean, students, eagerly awaiting his fate.
normalised: So, results season is upon us again! Honestly, it's like waiting for the monsoon – you know it's coming, you're kinda prepared, but the actual downpour can still catch you off guard. This year, the Class twelve results from C-B-S-E were announced on fifteenth May two thousand and twenty four, and the whole country went into a collective frenzy, I swear! My younger brother, Rohan, was one of the victims, er, I mean, students, eagerly awaiting his fate.

unnormalised: He'd been stressing about his Maths score especially. Last year his friend, Vivek only scored 65% in Maths, and the poor guy was worried he'd face the same fate. Thankfully, he did better this time around. It's funny how much importance we give to these numbers, right? It feels like your whole future hinges on that one percentage. Rohan scored 92% overall which to my surprise was even better than my elder sister! I remember my 10th class result, I managed to get a CGPA of 8.8, it was very average.
normalised: He'd been stressing about his Maths score especially. Last year his friend, Vivek only scored sixty five percent in Maths, and the poor guy was worried he'd face the same fate. Thankfully, he did better this time around. It's funny how much importance we give to these numbers, right? It feels like your whole future hinges on that one percentage. Rohan scored ninety two percent overall which to my surprise was even better than my elder sister! I remember my tenth class result, I managed to get a C-G-P-A of eight point eight, it was very average.

unnormalised: Remember those days where getting above 90% was like winning the lottery? Now, it's almost expected! The cutoffs for colleges are insane. Delhi University's first list went up to 99.5% for some courses last year. Talk about pressure! It also depends on the specific board. I remember an article I saw earlier this month that said that students from the ICSE board usually have a 5-10% higher percentage than state boards.
normalised: Remember those days where getting above ninety percent was like winning the lottery? Now, it's almost expected! The cutoffs for colleges are insane. Delhi University's first list went up to ninety nine point five percent for some courses last year. Talk about pressure! It also depends on the specific board. I remember an article I saw earlier this month that said that students from the I-C-S-E board usually have a five to ten percent higher percentage than state boards.

unnormalised: And let's not even start on the comparisons. "Sharmaji's son got 98%!" "Verma aunty's daughter topped the state!" It's a never-ending cycle. Our parents are even worse than we are, making us compare ourselves to our neighbour. What I realised is that these numbers don't define you. Yes, they're important for getting into certain colleges or fields, but they don't measure your potential, your creativity, or your passion. Rohan got 87/100 marks in Physics this year, which he was a little bummed about, as he expected a higher score.
normalised: And let's not even start on the comparisons. "Sharmaji's son got ninety eight percent!" "Verma aunty's daughter topped the state!" It's a never-ending cycle. Our parents are even worse than we are, making us compare ourselves to our neighbour. What I realised is that these numbers don't define you. Yes, they're important for getting into certain colleges or fields, but they don't measure your potential, your creativity, or your passion. Rohan got eighty seven divided by one hundred marks in Physics this year, which he was a little bummed about, as he expected a higher score.

unnormalised: It’s important to look beyond the marksheet. I always remind my brother what I got in Maths (just a pass!) and he usually stops talking after that. Look at all the entrepreneurs and artists who weren't academic geniuses, but still changed the world. It's all about finding what you're good at and pursuing it with dedication, regardless of what your marksheet says. In the end, Rohan was happy with his marks, and the entire household was in a celebratory mood.

In the end, Rohan was happy with his marks, and the entire household was in a celebratory mood.

unnormalised: So, if you're waiting for your results, remember to take a deep breath. No matter what the outcome, there's always a path forward. Your marks are just one part of the story, not the whole book. And hey, if things don't go as planned, there's always chai and samosas to make you feel better! Plus, if you're not happy with a mark, you can always apply for re-evaluation if the mark is very low. My neighbour's son actually increased his mark in maths by 5 marks.
normalised: So, if you're waiting for your results, remember to take a deep breath. No matter what the outcome, there's always a path forward. Plus, if you're not happy with a mark, you can always apply for re-evaluation if the mark is very low. My neighbour's son actually increased his mark in maths by five marks.

unnormalised: And parents, please, chill! Your kids are more than just numbers on a piece of paper. Support them, encourage them, and let them find their own path. That's the best gift you can give them. Remember that these marks don't define them in any way. Just be proud of them!
